awd_titl_txt: Neuromodulatory Control of Switching between Single and Dual Oscillatory Network States
awd_abstract_narration:
Networks of neurons are important for rhythmic behaviors such as walking, breathing, and chewing, as well as cognitive processes such as learning and memory. Flexibility of these rhythmic networks is essential for organisms to alter their behavioral output to meet changing demands. An important aspect of network flexibility is that neurons can rapidly switch their participation between networks. Modulatory inputs that project to rhythmic networks can induce neuronal switching through the release of chemical messengers. These chemical messengers alter network activity through their modulatory actions on the properties of neurons and on the synaptic connections between neurons. Determining how individual modulatory actions combine to elicit switching is a major challenge in the field of neuroscience. Small well-defined networks are instrumental in bridging the gap between cellular-level actions and whole network output. In particular, the crustacean stomatogastric nervous system (STNS) provides access to all network components as well as modulatory inputs to networks, and enables manipulation of individual neuronal properties and synaptic connections. This proposal uses the STNS to identify fundamental cellular mechanisms by which modulatory inputs switch neuronal participation between rhythmic networks. This includes the use of hybrid biological-computational networks to dissect the contributions of individual modulatory actions. This project also advances scientific discovery and learning for graduate and undergraduate students through training in the research lab of the principal investigator and in advanced lab-based courses. Underrepresented groups continue to be incorporated into the lab's research through partnerships with university and elementary school level STEM minority participation programs.
 
Interestingly, neuronal switching can include neurons that switch between single and dual network activity. This switching can result in a single neuron expressing two activity patterns at two different frequencies. There is some evidence that modulatory inputs can elicit switching through their actions on synapses and neuronal properties. However, the complex interplay of electrical coupling, chemical synapses, and neuronal membrane properties has limited research at the network level. An identified modulatory input in the STNS causes a neuron to partially decouple from its electrically coupled partners in one network and simultaneously participate in a second network. The objectives of this proposal are to determine how modulatory actions, individually and collectively, regulate switching between a single and a dual network state. These objectives are achieved using a combination of electrophysiological and computational approaches, including hybrid networks in which biological and model neurons are coupled with the dynamic clamp technique. This project aims to identify novel mechanisms by which modulatory actions enable a neuron to become an active contributor to: 1) rhythm generation for two rhythms simultaneously, despite their occurrence at different frequencies, and 2) coordination among different network neurons. Determining these mechanisms will provide new insights into how electrical and chemical synapses can interact with neuronal membrane properties to regulate participation between networks. Increased understanding of how electrical coupling interacts with other network properties also provides a framework for future biological and computational studies in other rhythmic neural networks including those in larger, less accessible systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Neural networks underlying rhythmic behaviors are highly flexible to enable adaptation to environmental signals and internal changes in behavioral state, such as hunger or stress for example. This flexibility extends to changes in the participation of neurons between neural networks, referred to as neuronal switching. The goals of this project were to examine neuronal switching in feeding-related regions of a crab nervous system to better understand how the participation of neurons between networks is controlled. We identified a novel mechanism in which the properties of the switching neuron itself were altered to change the neuron from participating in just one network, to simultaneously participating in two networks. This differs from the few previous examples of cellular mechanisms in which the strength of a connection from another network is enhanced to ?pull? a neuron into a second network. Our findings indicate that a switching neuron can become an integral player in a new network, in contrast with previous studies in which the switching neuron is only passively following input from a second network. Thus, for the many other circuits in which there is flexibility of neuron participation, it will be important to consider that the switching neurons may be recruited specifically to alter their own activity or they may be recruited to become essential to the production of a new circuit output. We identified support for this additional role of a switching neuron. Specifically, we demonstrated that the coordination between the switching neuron and other neurons in the second network occurs through enhancement of synapses in both directions between the switching neuron and second network neurons. This enables the switching neuron to play an active role in the particular version of network output, which ultimately will determine the particular version of a behavior. The separate mechanisms for recruiting a neuron into a different network and for determining its timing relative to other network neurons provides an additional degree of flexibility. In particular, this allows for a neuron to be recruited into a second network but be active with different types of coordination with the other neurons, allowing for more flexibility in the particular behavioral output.

As part of these main results, we identified some of the intrinsic properties that enable the switching neuron to generate activity in time with a second network, and that they interact with the synaptic input from the home network. Additionally, we determined that there can be multiple mechanisms enabling interactions between networks, such that one network can be regulated in distinct ways, at different time points, by a second network. This work demonstrates that there can be multiple control points coordinating behaviors, which is important for proper function for many related, co-active behaviors.

Results of the project were incorporated into an upper-level undergraduate course on neuromodulation developed during this project, and also contributed to an advanced research course at the Marine Biological Laboratory. Several lectures were recorded and made available to the public. Results from this project, and topics such as the use of model organisms in neuroscience research and the neural control of rhythmic circuits, was also introduced to elementary school students, including through participation in the ?STEM Girls Day Out? program, via hands-on activities. We also developed presentations on research topics, techniques, and moderated discussions about undergraduate participation in research, to high school students though the ?Neuroscience Summer Scholars? program and the ?Bridges? program for high-achieving high school students from historically underrepresented populations, and hosted these students for lab visits and demonstrations. Graduate students contributed to development, participation, and assessment of all of these outreach activities.

This project directly provided opportunities for six undergraduate students and four graduate students to gain extensive research experience in electrophysiological and anatomical approaches at the cellular to circuit level of the nervous system. Graduate students received training and experience in mentoring undergraduate students. All students received training and experience in reading and evaluating scientific literature as well as scientific communication in both oral and written format. Students attended internal, regional, and national scientific conferences and presented their research in poster and short talk formats. This included 34 presentations, 26 of which were at regional or national scientific conferences. Training an experience in scientific writing included student co-authorship (three undergraduate, three graduate students) on five peer-reviewed publications reporting results of this project. Additional student authors will also gain training and experience through four additional in-preparation manuscripts.
